Consider the linear applications 

$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y, z) & \longrightarrow & (y, x-z)
\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{cccc}
G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

Choose the right answer:
answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist
answer2: $(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$and $(G\circ F)$ does not exist
answer3: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$
answer4: $(G\circ F)(y, x-z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)(x, y)=(x+y, x-2y)$

A researcher studies the wind speed in a particular city. A sample of two hundred observations was recorded. The mean speed was calculated to be $10 m/s$ and the median speed was calculated to be $7 m/s$. Which of the following interpretations is correct?
answer1: $50\%$ of the sampled observations had speed that was less than or equal to $7 m/s$.
answer2: The most frequently occurring wind speed in the sample was $7 m/s$.
answer3: $50\%$ of the sampled observations had speed that was equal to $7 m/s$.
answer4: $50\%$ of the sampled observations had speed that was less than or equal to $10 m/s$.

Consider the subsets  $\displaystyle A=\{(1, 1, 1), (0, 1, 1), (1, 2, 3)\}$ and $\displaystyle B=\left\{(1, 1, 1), \left(-\frac{2}{3}, \frac{1}{3}, \frac{1}{3}\right), \left(0, -\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)\right\}$ of $\mathbb{R}^3$. Choose the right answer:

answer3: $A$ and $B$ are both orthogonal basis of of $\mathbb{R}^3$
answer4: $A$ and $B$ are both non-orthogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$

Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
4x & + & y & - & 5z & - & 3w & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x-y,\,x+y+1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question: Consider the nonlinear problem $ \min f(x,y,z)=(x-3)^2+(y+1)^2+z^2$. It is possible to say:

question: Choose the true statement.
answer1: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer2: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^4$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer3: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^2\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer4: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,x):x\in\mathbb{R}\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.

\[\begin{array}{ll}
\text{Maximize} & Z= 3x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
\text{subject to} & x_{1}\leq 4\\
& 2x_{2}\leq 12\\
& 3x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 18\\
& 3x_{1}+5x_{2}\leq 40\\
&  x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\ 
\end{array}
\]
answer1: All the points on the line segment connecting  $x_{1}=2 ,~x_{2}=6$ and $x_{1}=4 ,~x_{2}=3$ are optimal.
